ALAN SCHREIBER, Division Kirksville, MO 63501 (present address CPK: Dept. of Zoology, Louisiana State Univ., Baton Rouge, LA 70803) KARYOTYPES AND A RANGE EXTENSION OF REITHRODONTOMYS (CRICETIDAE: SUBGENUS APORODON) FROM MEXICO.-During the period 7 Dec.-4 Jan. 1980-81 we collected small mammals from various localities in southern M6xico. In this report we document a range extension of Reithrodontomys tenuirostris, describe its karyotype, and report a new karyotype for R.

Voucher specimens of karyotyped animals, all from Chiapas, Mexico, are deposited in the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, University of California, Berkeley (MVZ): Reithrodontomys mexicanus howelli, 5.1 mi SE (9 by rd.) Rayon, ca. 1450 m (2y9, MVZ 15920-21); R. tenuirostris, 13.5 mi NW (by rd.) Motozintla de Mendoza, Cerro Mozotal, 2850 m (1$, MVZ 161250). Karyotpic preparations and nomenclature of chromosome morphology follow Patton (J. Mamm., 48:27-37, 1967) . Material borrowed from the University of Michigan Museum of Zoology (UMMZ) aided our identifications.

Reithrodontomys tenuirostris was previously known from a few highland localities in Guatemala (Hall, Mammals of North America, Ronald Press, 1981). Our documentation of specimens extends the known range of this harvest mouse into Chiapas, Mexico, where it occurs at the following localities: Cerro Mozotal, 2850 m, (1, UMMZ); 13.5 mi NW (by rd.) Motozintla de Mendoza, Cerro Mozotal, 2850 m, (2, UMMZ); Cerro Tzontehuitz, 2910 m, (2, UMMZ). The UMMZ specimens were collected and identified by G. G. Musser in 1965 but were previously unreported. These distributional records correspond to the Evergreen Cloud Forest Formation (sensu Breedlove, Flora of Chiapas, Calif. Acad. Sci., 1981) , found only on the mountain crests in the Central Highlands (2000-2900 m) and the Sierra Madre (1900-3200 m) physiogeographic regions of Chiapas. For a list of common canopy and understory trees and shrubs characterizing this formation see Breedlove (op cit.).

The diploid and fundamental numbers of both Reithrodontomys mexicanus and R. tenuirostris are 52 and 50, respectively, the entire complement consisting of a gradation of large to small acrocentric elements (Fig. 1) . The karyotype of R. mexicanus from Chiapas differs from the description given by Carleton and Myers (J. Mamm., 60:307-313, 1979 ) of R. m. howelli from Guatemala and R. m.

Two minute hydra were in the stomach of one Umbra limi, and because they were attached to a large Diptera larva, we believe that the hydra were not the primary object of ingestion. Microscopic strands of filamentous algae (Chlorophyceae) were present in 23 U. limi, which included the smallest and largest individuals, and we believe them to have been accidentally ingested. A similar deduction was made by Peckham and Dineen (loc. cit.) in their study. We also suspect that the 20 diatoms (Bacillariophyceae) contained within eight stomachs were ingested accidentally. , 48:27-37, 1967) . Material borrowed from the University of Michigan Museum of Zoology (UMMZ) aided our identifications.

Reithrodontomys tenuirostris was previously known from a few highland localities in Guatemala (Hall, Mammals of North America, Ronald Press, 1981). Our documentation of specimens extends the known range of this harvest mouse into Chiapas, Mexico, where it occurs at the following localities: Cerro Mozotal, 2850 m, (1, UMMZ); 13.5 mi NW (by rd.) Motozintla de Mendoza, Cerro Mozotal, 2850 m, (2, UMMZ); Cerro Tzontehuitz, 2910 m, (2, UMMZ). The UMMZ specimens were collected and identified by G. G. Musser in 1965 but were previously unreported. These distributional records correspond to the Evergreen Cloud Forest Formation (sensu Breedlove, Flora of Chiapas, Calif. Acad. Sci., 1981), found only on the mountain crests in the Central Highlands (2000-2900 m) and the Sierra Madre (1900-3200 m) physiogeographic regions of Chiapas. For a list of common canopy and understory trees and shrubs characterizing this formation see Breedlove (op cit.).

The diploid and fundamental numbers of both Reithrodontomys mexicanus and R. tenuirostris are 52 and 50, respectively, the entire complement consisting of a gradation of large to small acrocentric elements (Fig. 1) . The karyotype of R. mexicanus from Chiapas differs from the description given by Carleton and Myers (J. Mamm., 60:307-313, 1979) All species in the subgenusAporodon karyotyped to date possess 52 chromosomes acrocentric. The existence of some R. mexicanus with a wholly acrocentric configu the totally acrocentric condition is probably primitive for the subgenus Apor Nat. Mus., 112:459-479, 1960) ; Jones (Trans. Kansas Acad. Sci., 67:509-516 1964) ; Gardner, et al. (J. Mamm., 51:712-729,1970 : 132-137, 1956 ). In the USA these fishes have been unintentionally introduced in several bodies of water, especially in Texas and Florida (R. R. Stickney, Proc. Fish. Nat. Mus., 112:459-479, 1960) . Previous recor include: Handley (Proc. U. S. Nat. Mus., 112:459-479, 1960) ; Jones (Trans. Kansas Acad. Sci., 67:509-516 1964) ; Gardner, et al. (J. Mamm., 51:712-729,1970) ; Honduras, unpublished record (Texas Cooperat Wildlife Collection, TCWC 18775); Greenbaum and Jones (Occas. Papers Mus. Texas Tech Un 55:1-7, 1978) .

body_text.text: Mist netting was carried out in areas of rain forest below 160 m elevation. The one adult m specimen of Mimon crenulatum keenani was netted at night over a circular body of clear, running wa surrounded on all sides by dense rain forest (an area called Blue Hole, located 20 mi south of Belmop 17? 08' N, 88? 42' W) . Measurements, in millimeters: total length, 87; forearm, 50.2; calcar, 18; hind fo 13; tail, 26 terminating half-way in a large uropagium. Dentition, i. 2/1, c. 1/1, p. 2/2, m. 3/3. Additional species collected at the Blue Hole location were Glossophaga soricina, Carollia brev cauda, Carollia perspicillata, Uroderma bilobatum, Artibius lituratus, Artibius phaeotis, Vampyro helleri. Two specimens of Rhynchonycteris naso were collected near the Belize River near the village

BIBREF15.raw_text: Mist netting was carried out in areas of rain forest below 160 m elevation. The one adult m specimen of Mimon crenulatum keenani was netted at night over a circular body of clear, running wa surrounded on all sides by dense rain forest (an area called Blue Hole, located 20 mi south of Belmop 17? 08' N, 88? 42' W). Measurements, in millimeters: total length, 87; forearm, 50.2; calcar, 18; hind fo 13; tail, 26 terminating half-way in a large uropagium. Dentition, i. 2/1, c. 1/1, p. 2/2, m. 3/3. Additional species collected at the Blue Hole location were Glossophaga soricina, Carollia brev cauda, Carollia perspicillata, Uroderma bilobatum, Artibius lituratus, Artibius phaeotis, Vampyro helleri. Two specimens of Rhynchonycteris naso were collected near the Belize River near the village Roaring Creek (four mi west of Belmopan, 17? 13' N, 88? 46' W).

KARYOTYPES AND A RANGE EXTENSION OF REITHRODONTOMYS (CRICETIDAE: SUBGENUS APORODON) FROM MEXICO.-During the period 7 Dec.-4 Jan. 1980-81 we collected small mammals from various localities in southern M6xico. In this report we document a range extension of Reithrodontomys tenuirostris, describe its karyotype, and report a new karyotype for R. mexicanus. Voucher specimens of karyotyped animals, all from Chiapas, Mexico, are deposited in the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, University of California, Berkeley (MVZ): Reithrodontomys mexicanus howelli, 5.1 mi SE (9 by rd.) Rayon, ca. 1450 m (2y9, MVZ 15920-21); R. tenuirostris, 13.5 mi NW (by rd.) Motozintla de Mendoza, Cerro Mozotal, 2850 m (1$, MVZ 161250). Karyotpic preparations and nomenclature of chromosome morphology follow Patton (J. Mamm.

MIMON CRENULATUM KEENANI (CHIROPTERA: PHYLLOSTOMIDAE) FROM BELIZE.-Thirty two bat specimens (17 skins and skeletons; 15 fluid preserved specimens) representin nine species collected by the author in Belize during June, 1975 are on deposit in the Vertebrate Resea Collection at Angelo State University. At least one of the nine species (Mimon crenulatum keenani) represents a new record from Belize a is uncommon in bat collections from Middle America. Identification was based on geographic distrib tion and description as reported by Handley (Proc. U.S. Nat. Mus., 112:459-479, 1960). Previous recor include: Handley (Proc. U.S.

FIGREF3.text: Conf. and Ann. Conv. of the Catfish Farmers of Texas, College Station, TX., July 20-21,1976; W. R. Courtenay and C. R. Robbins. Trans. Amer. Fish. Soc. 102:1-12). In some natural systems, thriving populations have become established (R. L. Noble, R. D. Germany, and C. R. Hall, Proc. S. E. Ass. Game and Fish Comm.: 1-29, 1975). In Texas, Sarotherodon mossambicus have established populations in the naturally warm and constant temperature headwaters of the San Antonio and San Marcos Rivers (T. M. Buchanan, Univ. of Tx. Ph.D. dissert., 1971). Prior to this report, no population of substrate spawning cichlids of the genus Tilapia have been reported from Texas. During February and March, 1979, cichlids were collected from a warm spring which feeds into the San Antonio River headwaters, and which passes through the San Antonio Zoo. Several specimens of S. mossambicus were collected, as well as eight specimens which were identified as Tilapia zilli on the basis of the following characteristics: Dorsal fin: XIV-XV-12-14. Pectoral fins 14/14 (one specimen 15/15). Anal fin: III, 9-10. L. L. scales (all scales showing pores were counted, from head to caudal peduncle): 17-19 upper/9-11 lower. Scales from origin of dorsal to L. L.: 6. Scales around caudal peduncle: 16 (one specimen 17). St. L.: 125-200 mm. Head: 32% of St. L. Body depth (measured from origin of dorsar to origin of pelvics): 40% of St. L. Eye orbit: 7% of St. L., 21% of Head L. Gill rakers: Outer rakers of first arch: 8-9 on lower half, 11-13 total. Inner rakers of first arch: 12-14 on lower half, A permit to collect specimens in Mexico was supplied by Ignacio Ibarrola Bejar, Direcci6n General del Departamento de Conservaci6n de la Fauna Silvestre. We thank P. Myers for allowing us to report on specimens housed in the University of Michigan Museum of Zoology (UMMZ) and R. J. Baker, M.D. Carleton, and J. L. Patton for comments on earlier drafts of this manuscript. This research was supported by grants from the Department of Zoology Graduate Research Allocation Committee, Louise M. Kellogg Grant-in-Aid from the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, the Tinker Foundation of the Center for Latin American Studies (to DSR), and NSF Grant DEB-78-12029 to J. L. Patton.-DUKE S. ROGERS, E. J. HESKE, AND D. A. GOOD, Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, 2593 Life Sciences Building, Berkeley, CA 94720. At least one of the nine species (Mimon crenulatum keenani) represents a new record from Belize a is uncommon in bat collections from Middle America. Identification was based on geographic distrib tion and description as reported by Handley (Proc. U.S.

TABREF2.text: Mist netting was carried out in areas of rain forest below 160 m elevation.The one adult m specimen of Mimon crenulatum keenani was netted at night over a circular body of clear, running wa surrounded on all sides by dense rain forest (an area called Blue Hole, located 20 mi south of Belmop 17? 08' N, 88? 42' W). Measurements, in millimeters: total length, 87; forearm, 50.2; calcar, 18; hind fo 13; tail, 26 terminating half-way in a large uropagium. Dentition, i. 2/1, c. 1/1, p. 2/2, m. 3/3. Additional species collected at the Blue Hole location were Glossophaga soricina, Carollia brev cauda, Carollia perspicillata, Uroderma bilobatum, Artibius lituratus, Artibius phaeotis, Vampyro helleri. Two specimens of Rhynchonycteris naso were collected near the Belize River near the village
